text: Jürgen Jürgens (5 October 1925 – 4 August 1994) was a German choral conductor and academic teacher. Born in Frankfurt am Main, he founded the award-winning Monteverdi-Chor Hamburg 1955. They recorded for Archiv Produktion, focussing on works of Claudio Monteverdi. Later the choir became involved in the Telefunken/Teldec Bach cantatas project with the Leonhardt-Consort. He died in Hamburg. ==Discography== * Heinrich Schütz St. Luke Passion, Max van Egmond, Peter-Christoph Runge – Jürgen Jürgens, 1966 * Monteverdi Lamento d'Arianna, Jürgen Jürgens, Monteverdi-Chor Hamburg, 1973 * Alessandro Scarlatti, Madrigals, Hamburg, 1975 * Schütz Die italienischen Madrigale, 1976 * Anton Bruckner Music of the St. Florian Period, 1984 – CD: BSVD-0109, 2011 (Bruckner Archive Production) * Bruckner Music of St Florian Period (II), 1985 – CD: BSVD-0111, 2012 (Bruckner Archive Production) ==References== == Further reading == * Robert Schomacker (ed.): JüJü – Jürgen Jürgens, der Monteverdi- Chor Hamburg und die Akademische Musikpflege der Universität Hamburg von den Anfängen bis 1994. Books on Demand, Norderstedt 2015, . ==External links== * * Jürgen Jürgens (Conductor) Bach Cantatas Website Category:1925 births Category:1994 deaths Category:German male conductors (music) Category:Musicians from Frankfurt Category:20th-century German conductors (music) Category:20th-century German male musicians
title: Jürgen Jürgens
